docs.lead_paragraph: Though national polls consistently point to nursing as one of the most trusted fields, the overall image of the profession seems to be in need of some doctoring. A recent survey of 1,800 American schoolchildren found that most saw nursing as a scary, stressful, low-status job with little career advancement, terrible hours and an ugly uniform. The nurse most recognized by the respondents? Carol Hathaway of ''ER,'' and the actress who played her left that television series last year.
docs.abstract: Recent survey of 1,800 American schoolchildren finds that most see nursing as scary, stressful, low-status job with little career advancement, terrible hours and unattractive uniform; experts in field worry that such perceptions contribute to severe shortage of nurses; nursing schools and hospitals are using number of marketing and advertising strategies to change perception (M)
docs.snippet: Though national polls consistently point to nursing as one of the most trusted fields, the overall image of the profession seems to be in need of some doctoring.    A recent survey of 1,800 American schoolchildren found that most saw nursing as a...

docs.lead_paragraph: On a personal level, the fear people feel when encountering a dog that has bitten them is fairly different from that felt when meeting one they have simply heard is dangerous. But from the brain's point of view, a recent study has found, the encounters have much in common. Writing in the April issue of Nature Neuroscience, researchers from New York University and Yale said they wanted to see how the brain processed threats of danger learned from personal experience, as opposed to those learned about from others. The discovery may lend insight into how people learn to fear, and how the body reacts in response.

headline.main: When the Brain Fears Fear Itself

docs.abstract: Comment on study on how brain processes threats of danger learned from personal experience, as opposed to those learned about from others (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Before you know it, life just passed you up,'' the man said. ''You lose everything. You lose your wife, you lose your family, you lose your friends.'' ''But after seeing you go back and forth to jail over 10, 15, 20 years,'' he added, ''they just give up on you.''

headline.main: For Users Of Heroin, Decades Of Despair

docs.abstract: Comment on findings of long-term study of aging drug addicts, in study published in The Archives of General Psychiatry; study, begun in mid-1970's by researchers at University of California at Los Angeles, followed male heroin addicts admitted to court-ordered drug treatment program in California in early 1960's; physical and social costs of addiction noted (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Dr. Albert Tzeel left San Francisco for his first real job in an established Phoenix pediatrics practice in 1990, he expected that move to frame his life and career for decades to come. In the last several months of his residency at the University of California, Dr. Tzeel had taken on moonlighting work to earn the down payment for a house. He and his wife decided to start a family, and they encouraged their parents, who were retired in Michigan, to move to Arizona for the warm and sunny climate.

headline.main: Doctors Now Need Well-Honed Skills In Job Hunting

docs.abstract: Job turnover among doctors is at all-time high, with more and more doctors working in managed care settings; medical journals are filled with advertisements of new employment opportunities, and every day physicians across nation receive queries from medical headhunters; physician turnover costs health care industry untold hundreds of millions of dollars per year, and has potential to harm patients; examples cited; photos (L)

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers at Yale may have found another upside to aging: they say national guidelines about weight gain should probably be relaxed for the elderly. In a study published this month in The Archives of Internal Medicine, Dr. Asefeh Heiat and Dr. Harlan M. Krumholz argued that there was little evidence that older people who were moderately overweight were at greater risk of illness or death. They cautioned that obesity and near obesity were still associated with an increased risk of death, even among people over 75.

headline.main: Extra Pounds Not as Risky in Elderly

docs.abstract: Researchers at Yale may have found another upside to aging: they say national guidelines about weight gain should probably be relaxed for the elderly, and there is little evidence that older people who are moderately overweight are at greater risk of illness or death (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The night light has long been a source of comfort for the young, to say nothing of the guidance it provides those adults who would otherwise stumble through the dark. But some researchers had theorized that the lights might cause nearsightedness in infants. Now, a new study reports that the concern appears unfounded. Writing in this month's Investigative Ophthalmology and Visual Science, scientists say they can find no link between myopia, the medical term for nearsightedness, and the lights.
docs.abstract: Study shows that fears that night lights can cause nearsightedness in infants are unfounded (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Put on your reading glasses or use a magnifying glass and take a look at the ingredients list on your skin care products. Do you see words like glycolic acid, alpha-hydroxyoctanoic acid, hydroxycaprylic acid, glycomer in crosslinked fatty acids alpha nutrium or even mixed fruit acid? Do you know what they mean, why they are there and whether they are safe to slather on your skin?

headline.main: Time to Review Your Cosmetics, Under Bright Light

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on health hazards of many cosmetics; notes informative new Web site on cosmetics produced by Food and Drug Administration lists any number of compounds that could, in some cases, cause more skin problems than they cure; examples cited; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The close association between diabetes and heart disease is a well-known medical phenomenon, but not among many of the people who are most affected, the people with diabetes. A survey made public yesterday found that only a third of diabetics realized that heart disease was among the ''most serious'' complications for which they were at risk, even though almost twice that number would experience a cardiovascular problem.
docs.abstract: Survey finds that only third of diabetics realize that heart disease is among most serious complications for which they are at risk (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The future's in a freezer in New Jersey. That's where our embryos are stored -- iced and awaiting further instructions. Pardon me for not getting excited, but we've been here before. After a couple of years of having nature laugh at us we switched to in vitro methods to augment faulty systems. Nothing's worked yet, but still we try.

headline.main: Learning to Laugh Through In Vitro's Indignities

docs.abstract: Alfred Lubrano Essay on efforts by him and his wife to have child by means of in vitro methods; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A study has found new evidence that the human brain continues to develop into the late 40's. The study, from the Department of Veterans Affairs, appears this month in The Archives of General Psychiatry. The lead author, Dr. George Bartzokis of the Central Arkansas Veterans Health Care System and the University of Arkansas, and his colleagues based their finding on a series of brain scans using magnetic resonance imaging technology.

headline.main: A Growing Brain, Even in Middle Age

docs.abstract: Study finds new evidence that human brain continues to develop into the late 40's (S)
